abstract: As Verizon begins to roll out FiOS in its hometown, New York, the company argues that the service is proving to be more successful than it promised when it started the project.
snippet: As Verizon begins to roll out FiOS in its hometown, New York, the company argues that the service is proving to be more successful than it promised when it started the project.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Verizon Communications embarked on an ambitious and expensive plan to run fiber optic cables, which can deliver ultra-fast Internet service and dozens of high-definition video channels along with old-fashioned telephone service, past 19 million homes, roughly half its territory.

headline.main: Verizon’s FiOS: A Smart Bet or a Big Mistake?
headline.print_headline: A Smart Bet Or a Big Mistake?

abstract: To listen to Craig Moffett, a top-ranked analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, Verizon’s $23 billion plan to build a fiber optic network for video, voice and data is going to destroy $6 billion of its shareholders’ capital.
snippet: To listen to Craig Moffett, a top-ranked analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, Verizon’s $23 billion plan to build a fiber optic network for video, voice and data is going to destroy $6 billion of its shareholders’ capital.
lead_paragraph: (UPDATE 4:24 p.m.| Peter W. Thonis of Verizon posted a lengthy response to this post on Verizon’s public policy blog, which another Verizon official reposted as Comment #54 below.)

headline.main: A Bear Speaks: Why Verizon’s Pricey FiOS Bet Won’t Pay Off
